title: Auto Approval of Invitation to join Team as a Team member

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hi Hackerone,

I have found a vulnerability wherein once a Team manager of any team sends out an Invitation to another Hackerone user to join his team, the invited team member gets auto accepted into the team to which he is being invited to join. 

The choice of "Accept" or "Reject" invitation which should have been displayed to the invited hackerone user is not not being displayed and the invited user without his knowledge becomes a Team member of the invited team

The above scenario will only happen when the invited user is not logged into his hackeone account. Once the invited user gets an email notification regarding the invite, he will just simply click on the invitation link provided in the mail.

The link will redirect the user to hackerone page wherein he either has to "Create" new hackerone account or Sign In with an existing hackerone account.

Once the user signs in with existing hackerone account, the automatically becomes a Team member of the invited team

Vulnerability:
===========
The invited hackerone user should have been directed to a page where he should decide to 'Accept' or 'Reject' the invitation. But since the above page was not being displayed, he became a member even though he didn't wanted to be or he wanted to reject.

Hope this is clear enough. Do note that the above scenario only works if the invited hackerone user is not currently logged into Hackerone when he received the invitation.

Regards,
Vivin Joseph

activities.message:
Please follow the below Scenarios as Proof of Concept.

Scenario [1] -- Normal workflow when the Invited User is already authenticated on to his Hackerone Account
************************************************************************************

1. User1 invites  User2 to be a member of his Team called "Test"(https://hackerone.com/vivin123)

2. User2 gets email about the invite.

3. User2 click on the "View Invitation" Link.

4. User2 is redirected to a page where he can select to "Accept" or "Reject" invitation.

5. User2 decides to choose either of the options depending on his decision. This is because User2 has the ultimate authority to decide if to join a team or not join the team.

The above is the accepted workflow as intended by Hackerone.


Scenario [2] -- Vulnerable Workflow when the invited user is not authenticated on to his Hackerone Account.
************************************************************************************

1. User1 invites  User2 to be a member of his Team called "Test"(https://hackerone.com/vivin123)

2. User2 gets email about the invite.

3. User2 click on the "View Invitation" Link.

4. User2 is navigated to page where he either has to complete the action by choosing between "Use Existing account" or "Create New Account".

5. User2 clicks on "Use Existing Account" and get navigated to Hackerone login page.

6. User2 enter valid login credentials and signs into his Hackerone account.

7. It was observed that Hackerone auto accepted the received invitation from User1 and User2 was navigated to the Test Team's(https://hackerone.com/vivin123) report page.

Observations:
* From the above it was very clear that Hackerone bypassed the "Accept" or "Reject" page for the invitation. 
* If the "Accept" or "Reject" decision was available to logged in user in Scenario[1], then the same should have been displayed to user in Scenario[2].

Conclusion:
The decision of "Accepting" or "Rejecting" an invitation should entirely rest with the invited User. Therefore, Hackerone must must correct its design flaw of auto approval of invitations(Scenario 2) and present to the user the interface for "Accepting" or "Rejecting" an invitation.

activities.message:
An Interesting Exploit:
=======================

When you create a Hackerone Team, by default you will become its Team manager. You cannot leave the team unless you invite someone else and assign that user as the Team Manager. Suppose you(User1) want to leave the team of which you are the only single manager, then by following the above steps as mentioned in Scenario[2], you can force another hackerone user(User2) to become a Team Manager(While sending the invite, Check the "Manage Team" check box).

Therefore, going with scenario[2], if User2 receives an invite to join a team and logins into his hackerone account, he automatically becomes the new manager of the Team. At this very moment, User1 can leave the Team as his "Leave Team" link becomes enabled. User1 immediately clicks "Leave Team" and exsits from the team he created.

Unkowing of what permissions was given to User2 by User1, if User2 now wants to leave the Team which he was forced joined automatically by Hackerone, he wouldn't be able to leave the team as he has become the new "Team Manager"(Its mandatory for each team to have minimum of 1 Team manager) 

User2 can only leave the team if he invites someone else(say User3) as the manager and that they(User3) accepts the invitation.

Inshort, User2 became the Team Manager of a Team which he didn't intend to join in the first place.Also due to the fact that he is now a Team Manager, he cannot leave the Team as there isn't anyone else as Team Manager in the Team. 

This is a serious design issue. Let me know if you agree with me..

activities.message: I wouldn't go of calling this as a CSRF attack :) , but nevertheless I was able to prove that an unintended operation (ie) forced approval of a Team invitation was possible on Hackerone. The scenario[2] is highly probable as most of the users checks their hackerone  and their emails separately and in most cases, the victims log into their mailbox first and on seeing the invite link, clicks on the same to login to hackerone account thereby falling victim to forced acceptance of the invitation.

activities.message:
I'm sorry but I can't reproduce the issue you're reporting. The flow I experience is:

1. A invites B to Team
2. B gets an email, clicks the link and is being showed a page to login or create an account.
2. B logs in an is showed the choice to accept or reject the invite

This is the flow that the user should expect and is completely normal. We don't bypass the Accept or Reject steps, so your conclusion seems to be flawed. Please provide a POC (video) which I can use to fully reproduce the issue you're experiencing.

Furthermore I don't agree it's a design issue that you're able to leave the team as a manager. Please submit a separate report if you really thing that is a security issue (but I wouldn't recommend that), or send us an email at support@hackerone.com to submit us your feedback (I recommend that).

activities.message:
@wvdv - By the way, just to clarify that this issue already created a major vulnerability which is forcing any Hackerone user to accept an invitation to Join an attacker controlled Team. Also, if the attacker gave the victim Manager permission, the attacker can then Leave the Team which he had created as there is another manager(victim) for the same team now. 

The victim on the other hand cannot leave the team as he has become the sole manager for it and by default there should be at least 1 manager per team. The victim now has to either contact Hackerone support or assign some1 else as the manager to the Team he had fell victim to so that he can come out of the team.

I know this is a bit complicated to follow but nevertheless its a serious issue which will cause a lot of confusion and disturb the overall user experience of the victim.

Do also note that to perform this check on Approved Teams as I couldn't do due to lack of approved teams.

**Offtopic**: the team is notified of your comments, we'll always get back to you. There is no need to ask for updates after a few hours. Please be patient.

I read your exploit scenario and I'm not convinced that it makes your report eligible for a bounty. The person joining the team can simply send an email to support to remove it from the team. The security team already thought of the potential consequences of your report, and we definitely would've paid you a bounty in case you thought of a realistic exploit scenario. For this report, you're recognized in our HoF and won't receive a bounty. Keep looking for awesome bugs. Happy hacking!
